abstract: According to Harry Shum, a Microsoft computer scientist, computer users will visit a Web site less if its loading time is slower than its competitors by 250 milliseconds, or one-quarter of a second. That is less time than a single eye blink.
snippet: According to Harry Shum, a Microsoft computer scientist, computer users will visit a Web site less if its loading time is slower than its competitors by 250 milliseconds, or one-quarter of a second. That is less time than a single eye blink.
lead_paragraph: According to Harry Shum, a Microsoft computer scientist, computer users will visit a Web site less if its loading time is slower than its competitors by 250 milliseconds, or one-quarter of a second. That is less time than a single eye blink.

headline.main: The Blink of an Eye? Oh, Please

abstract: In their new operating systems, Windows 8 and Mountain Lion, Microsoft and Apple are heading up the effort to make computers more like mobile devices.
snippet: In their new operating systems, Windows 8 and Mountain Lion, Microsoft and Apple are heading up the effort to make computers more like mobile devices.
lead_paragraph: BARCELONA, Spain — These days much of the action in the world of gadgets is happening in smartphones — like their sophisticated design and the apps that run on them. That has left desktop and laptop computers looking a little dull in comparison.

headline.main: Smartphones Have Led, and Desktops Will Follow

byline.original: By Jenna Wortham and Nick Wingfield
